properties.name: Allenholm Farm
properties.description: Posted by Newenglandgrown150 South Street, South Hero, VTOne guest suite with private deck available on 100 acre working farm/apple orchard. Petting paddock includes donkeys, sheep, horses, rabbits and goats. Country breakfast included. On-site farm store sells homemade applesauce, apple butter, jams, jellies, and pies made with fruit from the farm. Store also features an observation beehive. Guests may pick their own apples in the fall, press cider, and make hand-cranked ice cream. Moonlit wagon rides and school tours available. Justice of the Peace on-site. Open year-round.

properties.name: Baldwin Apple
properties.description: Posted by NewenglandgrownWilmington, MAThe traditional New England pie apple. Still very popular and not hard to find. Found by John Ball around 1740. Called "Woodpecker" by Mr. Butters, who later owned John Ball\'s farm. Finally became known as Baldwin for Captain Baldwin, who popularized the apple in the 1780s. A marker commemorated the spot where the original tree stood on Chestnut Street.

properties.name: Bar Harbour Cellars

Our vineyard will offer our own grapes by 2007.” Sustainable agriculture a priority. Farmhouse gift shop sells wine, fresh flowers and produce from the farm. Tastings offered daily (in season).

properties.name: Burbank Potato
properties.description: Posted by NewenglandgrownLunenberg, MANoted botanist/horticulturist Luther Burbank developed the Burbank potato in the 1870s, then sold the rights to the potato to James Gregory, who named it after him. From the Burbank potato came the Russet Burbank, the potato used in McDonald\'s French fries. Among his other accomplishments, Luther Burbank also developed the Santa Rosa plum, the Freestone peach and the Shasta daisy.

properties.name: Macomber Turnip
properties.description: Posted by NewenglandgrownWestport, RIFrom the historic marker in Westport: The saga of the Macomber Turnip Began on Main Road. Aiden and Elihu Macomber returned to Westport from the Philadelphia Exposition of 1878 with a prize in their pockets, Exposition turnip seed. Planted in these fertile fields, the crop developed with the years and became famous from Boston to Providence. There had never been a better turnip! Westport farmers still take pride in growing their pure Bristol Whites descended from Swedish and Russian Rutabagas with seed passed down from that trip to Philadelphia. The Macomber turnip is Westport\'s own, a symbol of pride and a treasure of mildness and sweetness that comes from our soil.

properties.description: Posted by Newenglandgrown 1 Old Sturbridge Village Road, Sturbridge, MA, 01566A nonprofit, educational museum that is open year-round. The centerpiece of the museum is a re-created rural New England town of the 1830s set on more than 200 acres of historical landscape, encompassing a Center Village, Mills Area, and Countryside. Kitchen garden displays vegetable, herb, and small fruit varieties commonly cultivated in New England in the early 19th century, also herb garden. Daily events including introduction to heritage breed farm animals, gardening workshops, spring maple sugaring demostrations, "farmers tool shed," and more.

properties.description: Posted by Newenglandgrown 200 Warfield Road, Charlemont, MA8 rooms available in 2 houses on 530-acre working farm. Breakfast included. 2 restaurants on-site (restaurants closed Mondays). Farm raises emus, Hereford beef cattle, Haflinger horses, chickens and llamas. Event/wedding/conference facility available. Event capacity: 160 - inside, 200 - outdoor pavilion. Llamas available for hikes. 2 hot tubs on-site.

properties.name: Watson Farm
properties.description: Posted by Newenglandgrown 455 North Road, Jamestown, RI, 02835-2238A working family farm. The farmers raise cattle and sheep for beef, lamb, and wool markets, grow acres of grass for winter hay supplies, make compost for fertilizer, and cultivate a large vegetable garden. The 1796 house, still used as the farmers\' residence, is not open to the public. Visitors are welcome to explore the farmland on their own, following a self-guided walking tour. Educational programs and group tours are available by appointment. Admission charged.
